word.entryDescription: to appear or start to exist suddenly or unexpectedly
word.entryExample: New housing is springing up all over the place at the moment.

word.entryDescription: to drop small drops of liquid or small pieces of food over the surface of something
word.entryExample: Sprinkle the grated cheese over the top of the pizza.

word.entryDescription: an open area in the middle of a town or city
word.entryExample: The square is full of shops and restaurants.

word.entryDescription: to fit into a small space
word.entryExample: The house is squeezed in between two other buildings.

word.entryDescription: a large structure consisting of a central area for playing sport surrounded by rows of seats for spectators
word.entryExample: I would like to see the new Olympic Stadium.

word.entryDescription: all the people who work in a place or for an organisation
word.entryExample: The staff at the restaurant were great – always cheerful and friendly.

word.entryDescription: a raised area in a theatre, concert hall, etc on which the performance takes place
word.entryExample: The theatre was very small and we were sat really close to the stage.

word.entryDescription: a series of steps that you use to walk up and down between levels of a building
word.entryExample: I think it's easier to take a lift than to go up the stairs.

word.entryDescription: old and no longer fresh
word.entryExample: The first cornflake was made from stale corn.

word.entryDescription: a table where things are sold
word.entryExample: There is also plenty to eat and drink and craft stalls all around the fair.

word.entryDescription: a small piece of paper that you need to buy and stick on a letter before sending it
word.entryExample: We’ve got to go to the post office. Mum needs us to get a stamp for my grandma’s card.

word.entryDescription: to be better or more noticeable than other people or things
word.entryExample: I have redesigned my CV so that I stand out more from the competition.

word.entryDescription: to move your body into a standing position
word.entryExample: The teacher says 'Stand up!'

word.entryDescription: bright balls of gas you can see at night that look like points of light
word.entryExample: How many stars are there in the sky?

word.entryDescription: containing a lot of starch (a carbohydrate present e.g. in potatotes, rice, flour)
word.entryExample: Is spicy chicken and rice a balanced meal? I guess it is – the chicken is good for protein, and the rice is a starchy food.

word.entryDescription: to do and then continue to do something that was not happening before
word.entryExample: School starts at 9 o'clock.

word.entryDescription: to begin your work
word.entryExample: I don't have to start work until lunchtime.

word.entryDescription: to establish your own company, shop, factory etc.
word.entryExample: If we had stayed in the city, my mum would not have started her own business.

word.entryDescription: a small dish usually eaten before the main course
word.entryExample: For my starter, I'd like a salad, please.

word.entryDescription: to suffer or die from lack of food
word.entryExample: They couldn't find food and starved to death

word.entryDescription: the political organization of a country
word.entryExample: Athens paid people for performing the functions that a democratic state required of them.

word.entryDescription: extremely shocked by something and unable to think or react normally
word.entryExample: He said he had been in a state of shock since winning.

word.entryDescription: a place where you can catch a train or bus
word.entryExample: Do you know where the bus station is, please?

word.entryDescription: numbers which represent facts
word.entryExample: Statistics show that people are richer than they were ten years ago.

word.entryDescription: an image of a person or animal, often large and made of stone or metal
word.entryExample: They wanted to see the Peter Pan statue.

word.entryDescription: social or professional position or rank of somebody/something in relation to others
word.entryExample: Hats can show the wearer's wealth and social status.

word.entryDescription: to be away from home during the evening or night
word.entryExample: I'm not allowed to stay out late during the week.

word.entryDescription: a thick slice of beef which is often grilled or fried
word.entryExample: I'll have the grilled steak with pepper sauce and chips.

word.entryDescription: (past simple: 'stole'; past participle: 'stolen') to take something without the owner's permission
word.entryExample: The Jules Rimet cup was stolen.

word.entryDescription: each individual movement of your legs when you are walking
word.entryExample: Neil Armstrong said, 'It's one small step for a man, one giant leap for mankind.'

word.entryDescription: a chemical substance that the body produces naturally or that can be made as a drug to treat illness and injuries, sometimes used illegally by people playing sports
word.entryExample: Too many athletes are tempted by steroids.

word.entryDescription: a dish made by putting meat and vegetables in liquid and then cooking it slowly in a pan
word.entryExample: Have you ever tried Irish stew?

word.entryDescription: up to a particular point in time and not finishing
word.entryExample: Will you still have the same hobbies in twenty years?

word.entryDescription: not moving
word.entryExample: My son finds it really hard to sit still.

word.entryDescription: to make something become more active
word.entryExample: The Spiral Garden is designed to stimulate the senses, like touch and smell.

word.entryDescription: a wound made when an insect stigns you
word.entryExample: This young girl is upset because she has a sting on her face.

word.entryDescription: to move an object such as a spoon around in a liquid in order to mix it
word.entryExample: A machine stirs the chocolate mixture until it's smooth and creamy.

word.entryDescription: to join together by sewing
word.entryExample: This skirt was stitched by hand.

word.entryDescription: to keep a supply of some kind of goods to sell
word.entryExample: Why don’t you see if the department store stocks your favourite parfume?

word.entryDescription: (of a person) short and strongly built
word.entryExample: He's rather stocky.

word.entryDescription: the part of your body where food goes after it leaves your mouth
word.entryExample: What's the matter with your stomach?

word.entryDescription: a pain in your stomach
word.entryExample: Alex has a stomachache.

word.entryDescription: a small piece of rock
word.entryExample: I found this beautiful stone when we went to the beach for a walk.

word.entryDescription: a long prehistoric period when humans widely used stone to make tools and weapons
word.entryExample: In the Stone Age, people used to make a kind of porridge by grinding grains with large stones.

word.entryDescription: to no longer do something
word.entryExample: The pirate stopped looking for the treasure.

word.entryDescription: a watch that you can stop and start, used for measuring the exact time it takes to do something
word.entryExample: The stopwatch says you took 5 minutes - that’s 30 seconds faster than last time!

word.entryDescription: the process of storing information in a computer memory
word.entryExample: They can't increase the memory storage of their tablet.

word.entryDescription: a violent weather event with a lot of rain or snow, strong winds and sometimes thunder and lightning
word.entryExample: Malaysia usually has very nice weather but yesterday there was a huge storm!

word.entryDescription: an account of something that happened, either true or imaginary
word.entryExample: She told me a funny story about her cat.

word.entryDescription: in a line that does not have any curves or bends or corners
word.entryExample: She has long straight hair.
